quiz.title: Unit 2: Production Possibilities Frontier (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: 2.6 Absolute Advantage: Productivity Comparisons in Trade (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Absolute Advantage, Productivity Measurement, Labor Productivity, and Trade Patterns

questions.question: A country has an absolute advantage in producing a good when it:
options: Has the lowest opportunity cost for that good
Can produce more output per unit of input than other countries
Has specialized in that good historically
Has the largest domestic market for that good
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage is about productivity - the ability to produce more output using the same amount of resources (or the same output using fewer resources) compared to other producers.

questions.question: Absolute advantage is primarily concerned with:
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage focuses on absolute productivity - how much output can be produced with given inputs, without considering the trade-offs or opportunity costs of producing other goods.

questions.question: If Country A can produce 50 cars with 100 workers and Country B can produce 40 cars with 100 workers, which country has absolute advantage in car production?
questions.explanation: Country A produces more cars (50) with the same number of workers (100), so Country A has absolute advantage in car production.

questions.question: A country can have absolute advantage in producing a good without having comparative advantage if:
options: Its opportunity cost is higher than other countries
Its productivity is lower than other countries
questions.explanation: A country can be the most productive (absolute advantage) but still have a higher opportunity cost for that good, meaning another country has comparative advantage despite lower absolute productivity.

questions.question: Which concept is more important for determining the pattern of trade?
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage (differences in opportunity costs) determines trade patterns, not absolute advantage. Countries trade based on their relative efficiencies, not absolute productivity levels.

questions.question: Country X: 1 worker produces 10 computers or 20 shirts. Country Y: 1 worker produces 8 computers or 16 shirts. Which statement is correct?
options: Country X has absolute advantage in both goods
Country Y has comparative advantage in computers
Country X has comparative advantage in shirts
questions.explanation: Country X produces more of both goods per worker (10 computers vs 8, 20 shirts vs 16), so Country X has absolute advantage in both goods. However, both have the same opportunity costs (1 computer = 2 shirts in both countries), so no comparative advantage exists.

questions.question: Absolute advantage is typically measured by:
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage is measured by productivity - output per unit of input (such as output per worker, output per hour, or output per unit of capital).

questions.question: If a country has absolute advantage in all goods, it:
options: Should not trade with other countries
Has comparative advantage in all goods
questions.explanation: Even with absolute advantage in all goods, a country can benefit from trade by specializing in goods where it has the greatest comparative advantage (lowest opportunity cost) and importing other goods.

questions.question: The concept of absolute advantage was originally developed by:
questions.explanation: Adam Smith developed the concept of absolute advantage in 'The Wealth of Nations' (1776), arguing that countries should specialize in goods they can produce most efficiently.

questions.question: Which situation demonstrates absolute advantage but not comparative advantage?
options: A country has lower opportunity costs for all goods
A country is more productive but has identical opportunity costs
A country has higher productivity and lower opportunity costs
A country has specialized in production historically
questions.explanation: When countries have different productivity levels but identical opportunity cost ratios, one has absolute advantage but no comparative advantage exists, so no beneficial trade is possible.

questions.question: In the real world, absolute advantage helps explain:
options: Why some countries are rich and others poor
The complete pattern of international trade
Why all countries benefit equally from trade
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage differences help explain income differences between countries - countries with higher productivity (absolute advantage) tend to have higher standards of living.

questions.question: A company has absolute advantage in production when it:
options: Has the lowest prices in the market
Can produce at lower cost than competitors
Uses more advanced technology than others
Has monopoly power in its industry
questions.explanation: At the firm level, absolute advantage typically comes from technological superiority that allows higher productivity - producing more output with the same inputs.

questions.question: If Country A's worker produces 6 tons of wheat or 3 tons of steel, and Country B's worker produces 4 tons of wheat or 2 tons of steel:
options: Country A has absolute advantage in both goods
Country B has comparative advantage in wheat
Trade will benefit both countries equally
Country A should export steel to Country B
questions.explanation: Country A produces more of both goods per worker (6 wheat vs 4, 3 steel vs 2), so Country A has absolute advantage in both. However, both have the same opportunity cost (1 steel = 2 wheat), so no comparative advantage exists.

questions.question: The main limitation of using absolute advantage to explain trade patterns is that it:
options: Cannot explain why countries with lower productivity still export goods
Overemphasizes the role of opportunity costs
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage alone cannot explain why countries that are less productive in all goods still export successfully. Comparative advantage explains this by focusing on relative opportunity costs.

questions.question: Labor productivity is a key measure of absolute advantage because it:
questions.explanation: Labor productivity (output per worker per time period) is a common measure of absolute advantage since it directly shows how productive workers are in different countries or industries.

questions.question: Countries often try to develop absolute advantage in key industries through:
questions.explanation: Countries invest in education, technology, infrastructure, and research to increase productivity and develop absolute advantages in high-value industries.

questions.question: In modern global trade, absolute advantage is particularly important for:
questions.explanation: Differences in absolute advantage (productivity) help explain why wages differ across countries - workers in high-productivity countries typically earn higher wages.

questions.question: If two countries have different absolute advantages but identical comparative advantages:
options: No mutually beneficial trade is possible
Only one country will benefit from trade
Trade will benefit both countries equally
questions.explanation: When opportunity cost ratios are identical (same comparative advantage), no basis for mutually beneficial trade exists, regardless of differences in absolute productivity.

questions.question: The relationship between absolute advantage and standards of living is that:
options: Countries with absolute advantage in many goods have higher living standards
Absolute advantage has no effect on living standards
Only comparative advantage affects living standards
Low-productivity countries always have high living standards
questions.explanation: Countries with higher productivity (absolute advantage) in many sectors can produce more goods and services per person, leading to higher material standards of living.

questions.question: A country can gain absolute advantage through:
questions.explanation: Countries develop absolute advantage by investing in technology, education, infrastructure, and innovation that increase productivity - the amount that can be produced with available resources.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You clearly understand absolute advantage and how it differs from comparative advantage in explaining trade and productivity.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand absolute advantage but review the key distinction: absolute advantage = productivity, comparative advantage = opportunity cost.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Absolute advantage means being more productive; it doesn't determine trade patterns; a country can have absolute advantage but not comparative advantage.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember: Absolute advantage is about who can produce more with the same resources. It's different from comparative advantage, which is about opportunity cost.
